questions.text: Which item below does not qualify as personal protective equipment? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lab coat

 

A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment.

 

While lab coats are worn in laboratory settings to protect clothing and skin from spills and splashes, they are not classified as PPE. PPE refers to more specialized equipment designed to provide a barrier against specific hazards.

 

Other 3 options are considered as PPE

 

Educational Objective:

 

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:

 

  • Gloves - protect hands.
  • Gowns/ aprons - protect skin and clothing.
  • Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents.
  • Goggles - protect eyes.
  • Face shields - protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.

questions.text: Identify the deformity shown in the image:(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cubitus valgus

 

CUBITUS VALGUS

 

  • Cubitus valgus is increased carrying angle which leads to displacement of the distal part away from the midline.
  • Carrying angle is the angle between long axis of arm and forearm. Its normal value is 5-15°.

 

 

  • Cubitus valgus is ost commonly caused by non-union of fracture around the elbow.
  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus is known for non-union and it involves growth plate hence, it causes cubitus valgus that can be progressive. In lateral condyle humerus fracture, cubitus valgus is much more common than varus.
  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late complication of progressive cubitus valgus.
  • The excision of head of radius in children may also produce cubitus valgus deformity and instability.
  • Treatment of cubitus valgus is by Milch Osteotomy with stable fixation using plates and screws.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gun stock deformity. Gun stock deformity or Cubitus Varus is reduced carrying angle in the elbow. It is most commonly seen in cases of malunion of fractures around the elbow. Supracondylar humerus fracture malunion is the most common cause of this deformity. As the fracture occurs above the growth plate, so it causes a static varus deformity. Lateral condyle fracture very rarely undergoes malunion. If this happens, there occurs a progressive cubitus

 

 

Option C. Coxa vara. It is the reduced angle between neck and shaft of femur due to some growth anomaly at upper femoral epiphysis (infantile type) or secondary to various other pathologies (acquired). The normal femoral neck shaft angle is 160° at birth, decreasing to 135 degrees in adult life. An angle of <120 degrees is called coxa vara. Congenital coxa vara can be due to congenital femoral deficiency, or developmental coxa vara. Acquired coxa vara can be due to SCFE, as a sequelae of AVN of femoral epiphysis, Perthes disease, femoral neck fracture, intertrochanteric fracture, rickets

 

 

Option D. Coxa valga. Coxa valga describes a deformity of the hip where there is an increased angle between the femoral neck and femoral shaft. It is often associated with shallow acetabular angles and femoral head subluxation. Coxa valga occurs when the angle formed between the neck of the femur and its shaft is increased beyond >140º. Normal is between 125-135º in adults, but can be 20-25º greater at birth and 10º greater in children. When the angle is <120º, this is considered coxa vara.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deformity shown in the image given in the question is called cubitus valgus which is the increase in the carrying angle. It is caused most commonly by non union of fracture around the elbow.

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Caesarean section

 

  •  The patient is a case of 
    • Preeclampsia 
    • Twin pregnancy (1st twin breech)
  • She is 38 weeks
  • As she is preeclamptic and has crossed 37 weeks, treatment would be to deliver her immediately. 
  • As the 1st twin is non cephalic, the mode of delivery is a cesarean delivery. 
  • Indications of cesarean delivery in multiple pregnancy:        
    • 1st twin non cephalic
    • Monoamniotic monochorionic twins
    • Conjoined twins
    • Triplets and above

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitor BP and terminate if BP rises: There is no indication to wait any longer as even in mild pre-eclampsia, delivery is done at 37 weeks. Waiting any longer is simply subjecting both mother and fetus to risks.

 

Option C. Terminate at 40 weeks: Again, this should not be done as in pre-eclampsia, delivery is planned at 37 weeks (mild) and 34 weeks (severe). This patient is already 38 weeks gestation

 

Option D. Induce labor with PGE2 gel: This patient should be delivered by cesarean section as she has twin babies, the 1st of twin is breech (non-cephalic). This becomes an indication for an elective LSCS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of preeclampsia with twin pregnancies where the first twin is in a breech position at 38 weeks, immediate cesarean section is the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the condition:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brodie’s abscess

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

 

  • It is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defence mechanism of body)
  • Seen in immunocompetent host.
  • This intraosseous abscess is related to subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis); e.g., Upper end of tibia
  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.

 

 

  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative)
  • Treatment: Trial of injectable antibiotics is given; if it fails, curettage of the cavity is carried out.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Intra-cortical hemangioma. Hemangioma of bone is a benign tumor that usually involves a vertebra or the skull and commonly is found as an incidental asymptomatic lesion.  They are slightly less commonly encountered in men (M:F = 0.7:1) and most commonly seen in the 5th decade of life but can occur at any age. These tumors are slow-growing and are most commonly asymptomatic unless they exert mass effect on sensitive structures, present as a swelling or a palpable mass, especially in the skull. Most commonly, they are located in the thoracic spine, followed by the skull and facial bones, followed by long bones where they preferentially involve the metaphysis or diaphysis.

 

 

Hemangioma of proximal femur

 

Option D. Chondromyxoid fibroma. Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare lesion of cartilaginous origin. Although chondromyxoid fibromas may occur at any age, most commonly occur in patients of 10-30 years old. Any bone may be involved, but the proximal tibia is the most common location. In contrast to other cartilaginous lesions, radiographic evidence of intralesional calcification usually is absent. Treatment consists of resection or extended curettage.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows Brodie’s abscess, which is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone, seen in subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is absent in the esophagus?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serosa

 

Explanation:

 

The esophagus is a tubular structure located in the thoracic cavity, connecting the pharynx to the stomach. Unlike most of the gastrointestinal tract, the esophagus lacks a serosa layer. The serosa is a thin membrane derived from the peritoneum, which is a structure found in the abdominal cavity. Since the esophagus is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, it does not have a serosa layer covering its external surface.

 

However, it is important to note that the short, intra-abdominal portion of the esophagus (just before it connects to the stomach) is covered by a serosa layer derived from the peritoneum. This portion is an exception to the general rule that the esophagus lacks a serosa.

 

The esophageal wall is composed of the following layers from the lumen outwards:

 

  1. Mucosa: The innermost layer, consisting of epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae.
  2. Submucosa: A layer of connective tissue containing blood vessels, lymphatics, and esophageal glands.
  3. Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria): Consists of an inner circular layer and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle.
  4. Adventitia: The outermost layer of the esophagus, composed of loose connective tissue. This layer is not called serosa because it is not derived from the peritoneum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucosa: Incorrect. The mucosa is present in the esophagus and forms the innermost layer.

 

Option B. Submucosa: Incorrect. The submucosa is present in the esophagus and lies between the mucosa and muscularis externa.

 

Option C. Muscularis externa: Incorrect. The muscularis externa is present in the esophagus and consists of two layers of smooth muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The esophagus lacks a serosa layer because it is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, except for the short intra-abdominal portion just before it connects to the stomach.

questions.text: A patient with hemolytic anemia presents with index finger pain and chest pain. The patient has Hb of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin in serum. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sickling crisis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with hemolytic anemia, evidenced by a low hemoglobin level of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, indicating hemolysis. The specific symptoms of index finger pain and chest pain are highly suggestive of a sickling crisis.

 

In sickle cell disease, patients may experience episodes of severe pain, known as sickle cell crises or vaso-occlusive crises, due to the blockage of blood flow by sickled red blood cells. The index finger pain (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome) are classic manifestations of such crises. Acute chest syndrome is a severe complication of sickle cell disease that presents with chest pain, fever, and pulmonary infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microangiopathic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells in small blood vessels but does not typically present with the specific symptoms of dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: While thalassemia also causes hemolytic anemia, it does not usually present with dactylitis or acute chest syndrome.

 

Option D. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the immune system attacking red blood cells but lacks the specific signs of sickle cell crisis, such as dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with hemolytic anemia presenting with severe pain in the fingers (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome), sickle cell crisis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: What levels of prolactin are definitely suggestive of prolactinoma? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 200 ug/L

 

Prolactin levels greater than 200 ug/L are definitely suggestive of a prolactinoma. This level typically indicates the presence of a prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma. The significant elevation in prolactin can cause clinical symptoms such as galactorrhea and amenorrhea in women, or hypogonadism in men. The diagnosis is further supported by imaging studies such as MRI, which can visualize the adenoma.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage

questions.text: A child presented to your clinic with complaints of severe respiratory distress, chin swelling, and difficulty in opening mouth. He gives a history of dental infection a week ago. Examination findings given below. What is the next step in management? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tracheostomy

 

Explanation:

 

The child presents with severe respiratory distress and swelling suggestive of Ludwig's angina, a severe cellulitis of the submandibular space. This condition can rapidly compromise the airway by pushing the anterior respiratory wall posteriorly, leading to obstruction. Given the severity of the respiratory distress, securing the airway is the priority, and tracheostomy is the recommended emergency procedure to ensure an adequate airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early intubation: While securing the airway is critical, intubation can be challenging and potentially hazardous in the presence of significant submandibular swelling.

 

Option B. External Incision and Drainage: This may be necessary after securing the airway but is not the immediate step in severe respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and Peroral Incision and Drainage: Antibiotics are essential, but in the acute setting of airway compromise, they do not provide immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe respiratory distress due to Ludwig's angina, a tracheostomy is the immediate step to secure the airway and prevent obstruction.

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of systole. In mitral stenosis, the loudness of S1 can vary depending on several factors. A loud S1 is typically associated with the early stages of mitral stenosis when the valve leaflets are still relatively mobile. However, in certain conditions, S1 can become softer.

 

In mild mitral stenosis without significant calcification usually results in a loud S1. This is because the mitral valve leaflets are still relatively mobile and can close forcefully. Therefore, mild mitral stenosis is the correct exception in this context, as it does not typically cause a soft S1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcified valve: When the mitral valve becomes calcified, it loses its mobility. This results in a softer S1 because the valve leaflets are not able to close rapidly or forcefully.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation can lead to an increased preload in the left ventricle, which can in turn affect the closure of the mitral valve, making S1 softer. Additionally, mitral regurgitation, which often coexists with mitral stenosis, can also soften S1.

 

Option C. First degree heart block: In first degree AV block, there is a prolonged PR interval. This delayed conduction can lead to a less forceful closure of the mitral valve, resulting in a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically seen in the early stages with mobile valves, while a soft S1 can indicate valve calcification, aortic regurgitation, or first degree heart block. Mild mitral stenosis without calcification usually results in a loud S1

choices.text: Angiotensin II

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. NO (nitric oxide)

 

Explanation

 

Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by CGMP.

 

Hormone-receptor complex activates the enzymes of the cell and causes the formation of another substance called the second messenger or intracellular hormonal mediator.

 

Second messenger produces the effects of the hormone inside the cells. Protein hormones and the catecholamines act through second messenger. Most common second messenger is cyclic AMP.

 

NO activates guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger) which activates cGMP dependent protein kinase, that causes blood vessels to relax.

 

Cyclic GMP is synthesized from the nucleotide GTP using the enzyme guanylyl cyclase. Cyclic GMP serves as the second messenger for

 

  1. atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
  2. nitric oxide (NO)
  3. the response of the rods of the retina to light

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin: Incorrect because somatostatin typically acts through inhibition of adenylate cyclase, thus reducing cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, not through cGMP.

 

Option B. Angiotensin II: Incorrect as angiotensin II primarily acts through the phosphatidylinositol signaling pathway and does not utilize cGMP as a second messenger.

 

Option C. ADH: Incorrect because antidiuretic hormone (ADH) primarily utilizes cAMP as its second messenger, particularly in its renal actions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitric oxide (NO) uses cGMP as its second messenger to mediate vasodilation. NO activates guanylyl cyclase, increasing cGMP levels in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to vessel relaxation. This highlights cGMP's role in cardiovascular function and its importance in the regulation of blood pressure.

choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.text: Which of the following statement is True regarding trematodes? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Of the given statements regarding trematodes, the only true statement is that Fasciola hepatica is seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

 

Fasciola hepatica is the largest and most common liver fluke found in man

 

Habitat - The parasite resides in the liver and biliary passages of the definitive host.

 

Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle and man.

 

Intermediate host: Snails

 

Mode of infection: The definitive host, sheep and man, get infection by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

 

Life cycle-

 

 

Unlike other trematodes and basically all other flatworms, the schistosomes are dioecious, i.e., the sexes are separate

 

Schistosoma – Cercariae penetrates through skin, eggs with terminal spine, only snails as intermediate hosts and separate sexes.

 

Praziquantel remains the drug of choice for all trematode infections except fascioliasis, for which triclabendazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schistosoma are monoecious: This statement is false. Schistosomes are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes (male and female), which is an exception among trematodes, as most are hermaphroditic.

 

Option C. Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water: This statement is false. Fasciola hepatica infection is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation, not directly through contaminated water.

 

Option D. Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections: This statement is false. While triclabendazole is the drug of choice for fascioliasis, praziquantel remains the drug of choice for most other trematode infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fasciola hepatica is found in the intrahepatic biliary radicles of its definitive host. It is acquired through ingestion of metacercariae on aquatic vegetation, and its treatment of choice is triclabendazole. Schistosomes, unlike other trematodes, are dioecious, meaning they have separate sexes.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fever and joint pain develops the following lesion on her nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig: Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Dengue:

 

  • While dengue fever is also a mosquito-borne viral infection leading to symptoms like fever, headache, and joint pains, it does not typically result in brownish pigmentation on the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

The most likely organism based on the description of the microfilariae is Brugia malayi.

 

The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei - a terminal and a subterminal one. It has nocturnal periodicity.

 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae.

 

Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis but does not have two distinct nuclei at the tail tip of its microfilariae.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Known for daytime periodicity and does not show the characteristic two nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Does not circulate in peripheral blood; instead, its microfilariae are found in skin and connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: An antiemetic was given to a chemotherapy patient, who then developed symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following medications would have resulted in these symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metoclopramide

 

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and a prokinetic drug that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can be given IV and it can cross the Blood brain barrier, thereby leading to D2 receptor block in the brain which can have side effects like acute dystonia, abnormal movements and drug induced Parkinsonism.
  • In such cases, to treat them, drugs having central anticholinergic action like Benzhexol are used. They work by resorting the balance that has been disrupted by having a relative cholinergic excess in the striatum due to dopaminergic blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It is commonly used as an antiemetic, especially in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, but it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects like metoclopramide. Its side effect profile mainly includes headaches, constipation, and QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Meclizine: Meclizine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, used primarily to treat motion sickness and vertigo. It does not block dopamine receptors and therefore does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Scopolamine: Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly motion sickness. It works by blocking acetylcholine receptors and does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. Its side effects include dry mouth, dizziness, and blurred vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide, an antiemetic that acts by blocking D2 receptors, can cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors.

choices.text: Prolonged second stage

questions.text: Which of the following situations is not managed by using Ventouse for a delivery? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premature baby

 

Explanation:

 

Ventouse assisted delivery can cause Intracranial hemorrhage in a preterm fetus

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged second stage: Ventouse is commonly indicated for prolonged second stage of labor to assist in the delivery process.

 

Option B. Maternal Exhaustion: Maternal exhaustion is another indication for operative vaginal delivery using either forceps or ventouse to expedite delivery and reduce maternal strain.

 

Option C. Fetal Distress: Fetal distress is an indication for immediate delivery, and ventouse can be used to quickly assist in the delivery when immediate intervention is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventouse-assisted delivery is contraindicated in premature babies due to the risk of intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Ref: D.C. Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 652,661

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

 

The angle subtended for a patient with 6/6 vision is 5 minutes of arc.

 

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

 

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size. Each whole letter will subtend the angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials is drug dosing determined? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phase 1

 

Phase 1 clinical trials are the first stage of testing in human subjects and are primarily concerned with evaluating the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a drug. During this phase, researchers determine the most appropriate dosage range and identify any potential side effects. The goal is to establish the drug's safety profile, including the maximum tolerable dose.

 

While Phase 2 trials do involve further assessment of dosing, particularly in terms of efficacy and dose-ranging studies, the initial determination of safe and effective dosing begins in Phase 1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phase 2: Phase 2 trials focus more on evaluating the efficacy of the drug and further investigating the optimal dosing regimens (Dose ranging studies) identified in Phase 1. However, the primary determination of dosing occurs in Phase 1.

 

Option C. Phase 3: Phase 3 trials are large-scale studies conducted to confirm the efficacy and monitor adverse reactions in a larger population, comparing the new drug to existing treatments.

 

Option D. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug has been approved for public use and are designed to monitor long-term effectiveness and safety in the general population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial determination of drug dosing is primarily conducted during Phase 1 of clinical trials, where the safety and tolerability of the drug are assessed.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with a normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesion and a history of prolonged fever in childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the absence of thickened nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis.

 

Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.

 

The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B
  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.
  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.
  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 33 page no 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is preferred in anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ulnar Nerve

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting.
  • By stimulating this nerve, we can observe the twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle in the hand, which is representative of deeper muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.
  • The ulnar nerve is easily accessible and provides consistent responses.

 

Why it's preferred:

 

  • Neuromuscular monitoring aims to ensure that patients have adequate muscle paralysis during surgery and complete recovery from paralysis before waking up.
  • The ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle combination has a similar sensitivity to neuromuscular blocking drugs as the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles, which are critical for breathing and airway protection.
  • Using a Train of Four monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator, the ulnar nerve is stimulated to observe the twitch response, allowing anesthesiologists to gauge the depth of neuromuscular blockade and adjust drug dosages accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median Nerve: The median nerve is less commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring because it does not provide as consistent or reliable a response as the ulnar nerve. The muscle response to stimulation of the median nerve may not accurately reflect the status of deeper muscles.

 

Option C. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve innervates muscles that primarily affect the extension of the wrist and fingers. While it can be used for monitoring, it is not the preferred choice because it is less sensitive to neuromuscular blocking agents compared to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Mandibular Nerve: The mandibular nerve is not used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in the clinical setting. It is part of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) and does not provide a useful twitch response for assessing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the preferred nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade in anesthesia due to its accessibility and reliable twitch response of the adductor pollicis muscle, which reflects the status of critical muscles like the diaphragm and laryngeal muscles.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 834

choices.text: Conservative management is the mainstay therapy
Posture of finger is in extension
Pain on passive extension of finger

questions.text: True about acute tenosynovitis is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive extension of finger

 

ACUTE SUPPURATIVE TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • It is purulent infection of synovial flexor sheath.
  • It may be the result of the spread of adjacent pulp infections or puncture wounds in the flexor creases.

 

 

  • Although the flexor sheath is usually involved, the radial and ulnar bursae may be involved as well.
  • Most common organism – Staphylococcus aureus
  • Most common digits involved – Ring, middle and index fingers
  • Kanavel’s sign:
    • Rigid positioning of finger in flexion
    • Tenderness over tendon sheath (most significant)
    • Severe pain on passive extension of involved digit
    • Fusiform swelling of involved digit

 

 

  • Treatment
    • Immediate treatment with antibiotics and splinting may abort spread of the infection, if symptoms present for less than 48 hours.
    • Established pyogenic tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency – prompt surgical drainage along with antibiotics.
    • If drainage is required, an open or closed irrigation technique can be used.
    • If an open technique is used, healing and rehabilitation are prolonged, and full motion may not be regained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative management is the mainstay therapy. This statement is false. They gold standard treatment is irrigation and debridement of the flexor sheath.

 

Option B. More commonly involves thumb. This is statement is incorrect. The index, middle and ring fingers are more commonly involved.

 

Option C. Posture of finger is in extension. This statement is incorrect. The affected finger remains in flexion. There is pain on active or passive extension of the finger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute suppurative tenosynovitis of the finger is a purulent infection of the flexor tendon sheath of the finger.

questions.text: Treatment of benzodiazepine overdose? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flumazenil

 

Flumazenil is the drug of choice for treating benzodiazepine overdose. It acts as a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor, effectively reversing the effects of benzodiazepines. By administering flumazenil, the respiratory depression and sedation caused by benzodiazepine overdose can be counteracted, making it a crucial antidote in such situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fomepizole is incorrect as it is used in the treatment of methanol toxicity, not benzodiazepine overdose. Fomepizole acts as an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor, preventing the metabolism of methanol to its toxic metabolites.

 

Option C. Naltrexone is incorrect as it is primarily used for the treatment of alcohol relapse and opioid dependence, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist that helps reduce cravings and prevents the rewarding effects of alcohol and opioids.

 

Option D. Naloxone is incorrect as it is the drug of choice for opioid overdose, not benzodiazepine overdose. Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioids, including respiratory depression and sedation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine overdose, acting as a competitive antagonist at the GABA-A receptor.

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, the approach to vaccination must be carefully considered, particularly due to their immunocompromised state from corticosteroid therapy.

 

  • Killed (inactivated) vaccines are safe and can be administered to these children as they do not pose a risk of causing disease. This includes vaccines such as the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine, and others under the National Immunization Schedule (NIS).
  • Live vaccines should be administered with caution. For children on corticosteroid therapy, live vaccines (e.g., MMR, varicella) are generally avoided unless the child is on low-dose corticosteroids (less than 1 mg/kg/day of prednisone or equivalent). Live virus vaccines are contraindicated in children receiving high doses of steroids or other immunosuppressive therapies like cyclophosphamide or cyclosporine.
  • Vaccination of household contacts: It's crucial to vaccinate healthy household contacts with live vaccines to protect the immunosuppressed child indirectly. However, precautions should be taken to avoid contact with the secretions of recently vaccinated individuals, particularly in the case of live oral vaccines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule: This is not accurate as live vaccines should be given with caution or avoided in immunocompromised children, particularly those on high-dose steroids.

 

Option C. Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in the acute phase: While the pneumococcal vaccine is important, it is not the only vaccine that should be considered. Killed vaccines are generally safe and should be administered according to the vaccination schedule.

 

Option D. Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling: This is incorrect. Siblings and household contacts should receive live vaccines to reduce the risk of transmitting infections to the immunocompromised child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines under the National Immunization Schedule can be safely administered, while live vaccines should be given with caution depending on the child's immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

questions.text: Which one is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purulent conjunctivitis

 

Purulent conjunctivitis is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease. Instead, the conjunctivitis seen in Kawasaki disease is non-purulent and sterile, meaning it does not produce pus, and cultures are negative.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute, self-limited vasculitis that predominantly affects children. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease include the presence of fever for at least five days, along with at least four of the following five clinical features:

 

  1. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (conjunctivitis): This is a common feature in Kawasaki disease, but it is non-purulent (does not produce pus).
  2. Changes in the lips and oral cavity: This includes strawberry tongue (a red, bumpy tongue), erythema, and cracking of the lips.
  3. Polymorphous rash: A rash of various forms can be present.
  4. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Typically unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm in diameter.
  5. Changes in the extremities: This includes erythema of the palms and soles, edema of the hands and feet, and later desquamation (peeling) of the skin.

 

TOC - IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) ± Aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rash: A polymorphous rash is one of the key diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is another diagnostic criterion, usually unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm.

 

Option D. Strawberry tongue: Changes in the lips and oral cavity, including strawberry tongue, are diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is diagnosed based on a set of clinical criteria, including non-purulent conjunctivitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, and changes in the oral cavity such as strawberry tongue. Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Melanoma, on the other hand, is a type of skin cancer primarily associated with UV exposure and is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. Although people with HIV/AIDS might have a higher risk of developing melanoma due to their immunocompromised state, it is not specifically used to define AIDS.

 

AIDS-defining malignancies are specific types of cancer that are more likely to occur in people with AIDS. These cancers are used in the clinical definition of AIDS because they are directly associated with the immunosuppression caused by the HIV virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kaposi's sarcoma: This cancer is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is one of the most common AIDS-defining cancers. It manifests as vascular tumors that can appear on the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Invasive cervical carcinoma: This cancer is linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the increased risk in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Particularly the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma, are common in AIDS patients due to the compromised immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

questions.text: Apoptotic bodies comprise of: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytoplasm + nuclear fragment + organelle

 

Apoptotic bodies are formed during the process of apoptosis, or programmed cell death. Apoptosis involves the activation of caspase enzymes, endonucleases, and proteases, leading to the fragmentation of the dying cell. These cellular fragments, known as apoptotic bodies, contain components of the cell, including cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles. The presence of these components within the apoptotic bodies is a key characteristic of the apoptotic process.

 

 

 

 

TUNEL Staining (Mouse liver showing an apoptotic cell stained with TUNEL)

Apoptotic body is looks like a dense, eosinophilic structure,  the presence of a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis and TUNEL staining, which are both associated with the detection of apoptotic cells. These techniques help identify the fragmented DNA and cellular components present in apoptotic bodies.

 

 

Lane B – showing apoptosis as a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptotic bodies, formed during the process of apoptosis, comprise cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles of the dying cell.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes conjunctival xerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency leads to a condition called xerophthalmia, which causes conjunctival xerosis, also known as dry eye. Xerophthalmia can be classified into two types: primary and secondary.

 

Primary xerophthalmia has five categories:

 

  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis (dry eye)
  • X1B: Bitot's spots (a specific manifestation)
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration
  • X3B: Keratomalacia

 

Secondary manifestations of xerophthalmia include:

 

  • XN: Night blindness
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus
  • XS: Xerophthalmic scarring

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "4 D's" (diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death). It does not directly cause conjunctival xerosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects in developing fetuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency causes xerophthalmia, which leads to conjunctival xerosis (dry eye) and other ocular manifestations, including Bitot's spots, corneal xerosis, corneal ulceration, and keratomalacia.

choices.text: Identify the source of bleeding
Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding in the external auditory canal following trauma. The next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

 

Given the situation of trauma and the presence of blood in the external auditory canal, the most appropriate next step is to keep the ear dry to avoid any additional complications and to provide oral medications for pain, possible infection, and to reduce inflammation.

 

Keeping the ear dry and giving oral medications is a standard approach for managing a bloody discharge from the ear following trauma. This usually includes avoiding water in the ear to prevent infection and prescribing oral antibiotics if there is a suspicion of bacterial infection. Pain relief medication may also be provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirating the clot is generally not the first step in management unless there's a need for immediate assessment of the underlying structures, and if there's concern for ongoing bleeding that may be occluding the canal and impeding examination.

 

Option B. Identifying the source of bleeding is important, especially if the bleeding is significant or ongoing. However, this would typically follow initial conservative management unless the bleeding is profuse.

 

Option D. Syringing (ear irrigation) is contraindicated in the presence of a bloody discharge following trauma, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and increase the risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After trauma to the external auditory canal with bloody discharge, it is important to keep the ear dry and initiate treatment with oral medications, such as analgesics and possibly antibiotics, to manage pain, prevent infection, and reduce inflammation.

questions.text: Patient can see 3 green dots on the Worth’s 4 dots test. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RE suppression

 

The Worth 4-dot test is used to evaluate binocular vision and identify suppression of one eye or diplopia. The patient wears red-green goggles where the Red lens is over the Right eye (RE) and the green lens is over the left eye (LE). Normally, a person should see four dots: one red, two green, and one white dot that appears either as red, green, or mixed (brown), depending on which eye is dominant or if both eyes are functioning equally.

 

If a patient sees only three green dots, it indicates suppression of the right eye (RE). This is because the right eye, which should see the red dot, is not contributing to the vision, leading the patient to perceive only the green dots seen by the left eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crossed diplopia: In crossed diplopia, images from the right eye appear on the left side and vice versa, causing overlapping images. This does not match the scenario where only three green dots are seen.

 

 

Option B. Uncrossed diplopia: Uncrossed diplopia occurs when images appear on the same side as the eye seeing them. It would involve seeing more dots (double vision) rather than missing a dot due to suppression.

 

 

Option D. LE suppression: Left eye suppression would result in the patient seeing only two red dots, as the left eye is not contributing to the vision. This does not match the observed scenario of seeing three green dots.

 

Educational Objective:


Seeing three green dots on the Worth 4-dot test indicates right eye suppression (RE suppression), as the right eye is not seeing the red dot.

questions.text: In which of the following infections do both partners need to be treated? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. In cases of trichomoniasis, it is essential to treat both the infected individual and their sexual partner(s) to prevent reinfection and to control the spread of the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis (BV): Although BV is associated with an increased risk of acquiring STIs, it is not classified as an STI itself. Therefore, routine treatment of sexual partners is not recommended.

 

Option B. Candidiasis: This is typically caused by an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly Candida albicans, and is not considered an STI. Treating the sexual partner is not usually necessary unless the partner has symptoms of candidiasis.

 

Option D. Genital TB: This is primarily spread through hematogenous (blood) or lymphatic routes rather than sexual transmission. Partners are not treated unless they are also diagnosed with genital tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For trichomoniasis, both partners need to be treated to prevent reinfection and control the spread of the disease.

questions.text: What importance does the point labelled as 'C' hold? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Onset of symptoms

 

  • The given image depicts timeline of natural history of disease in an individual over time, in which the point labelled C denotes the onset of symptoms.

 

 

 

  • Natural history of disease describes the natural course of the disease from its early pre pathogenesis phases to termination.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The onset of symptoms marks the transition from the subclinical stage to the clinical stage of disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with seizures. On further evaluation, there was also a history suggestive of manic and depressive episodes. Which of the following drugs should be prescribed?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

The patient has a history of both seizures and bipolar disorder, characterized by manic and depressive episodes. Valproate (also known as valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant medication that is effective in treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder. It helps in stabilizing mood and preventing both manic and depressive episodes, making it an appropriate choice for patients with comorbid bipolar disorder and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregabalin: This drug is primarily used for neuropathic pain and certain anxiety disorders; it is not effective in the treatment of bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: This is an anticonvulsant used to treat seizures but does not have mood-stabilizing properties needed for bipolar disorder.

 

Option D. Levodopa: This is primarily used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and has no role in the management of seizures or bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Valproate is effective for treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder, making it the drug of choice for patients with comorbid conditions.

questions.text: Identify the condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Jejunal atresia

 

The image provided shows a characteristic "triple bubble" sign, which is indicative of jejunal atresia. Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where there is an absence or closure of a portion of the jejunum, leading to intestinal obstruction.

 

The radiographic finding of the triple bubble sign is due to the accumulation of gas in the stomach, duodenum, and the proximal jejunum, which are isolated by the atresia from the rest of the intestines. This results in three distinct gas-filled areas visible on the X-ray, hence the term "triple bubble."

 

In the context of the provided options, the diagnosis is most consistent with jejunal atresia based on this radiographic sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyloric stenosis: Pyloric stenosis typically presents with a "single bubble" sign on X-ray, representing gas in the stomach only due to obstruction at the level of the pylorus.

 

Option B. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia presents with a "double bubble" sign, showing two gas-filled areas (stomach and duodenum) separated by the atresia. This is different from the triple bubble sign seen in jejunal atresia.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: While intestinal obstruction can cause various radiographic signs, the specific "triple bubble" sign is most characteristic of jejunal atresia rather than a general obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "triple bubble" sign on an X-ray is indicative of jejunal atresia, a congenital obstruction of the jejunum.

questions.text: The following condition is seen in: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis

 

Based on the provided chest X-ray, which shows numerous rounded opacities throughout the lung fields.

 

This would appear on an X-ray as multiple well-circumscribed nodules scattered throughout the lung fields known as “Cannon-ball” metastasis. The pattern seen in the image provided is consistent with lung metastasis, where the primary cancer elsewhere in the body has spread to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Miliary TB: This is characterized by numerous small nodules throughout the lung parenchyma resembling millet seeds, hence the term "miliary." These nodules are usually uniform in size.

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: Depending on the stage, aspergillosis can present with various radiographic appearances, from a 'fungal ball' within a pre-existing cavity (aspergilloma) to invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, which typically presents with consolidation and/or nodules, often with a halo sign.

 

Option C. Consolidation: This refers to an area of the lung where alveolar air is replaced by fluid, cells, or other substances, which on an X-ray appears as a homogenous increase in pulmonary parenchymal density. The borders of the affected area are usually indistinct and not nodular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The chest X-ray findings of multiple well-circumscribed nodules throughout the lung fields are indicative of lung metastasis, representing the spread of cancer from another part of the body to the lungs.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraglottic

 

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions.
  • Types of stridor and sites of origin
    • Inspiratory stridor - laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
    • Expiratory stridor - bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
    • Biphasic stridor - laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis and subglottic stenosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subglottic - More commonly associated with biphasic stridor due to narrowing at the level just below the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Tracheal - Can cause either biphasic or expiratory stridor depending on the extent and exact location of the obstruction.

 

Option D. Bronchus - Primarily causes expiratory stridor due to obstructions in the lower airways.

 

Educational Objective:


Inspiratory stridor is a key clinical sign indicating a potential obstruction in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing this symptom is critical for diagnosing and managing airway obstructions effectively to prevent respiratory distress.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 333, 334

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending, and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination you note areflexia. Pain and proprioception are preserved. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Guillain Barre syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system. It is often preceded by an infection such as a respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infection. The hallmark features of GBS include:

 

  1. Acute onset: Symptoms develop rapidly.
  2. Ascending weakness: The weakness starts in the lower limbs and ascends to the upper limbs.
  3. Symmetrical nature: The weakness affects both sides of the body equally.
  4. Areflexia: Absence of reflexes.
  5. Flaccid paralysis: The muscles become weak and floppy.

 

The patient's history of a respiratory infection 4 weeks ago (acute) followed by progressive, symmetrical ascending areflexia and flaccid quadriparesis the classic presentation of GBS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Myasthenia gravis: This condition typically presents with fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Deep tendon reflexes remain normal. It does not present with ascending weakness.

 

Option C. Polymyositis: This is an inflammatory muscle disease that causes symmetric proximal muscle weakness. It does not present with ascending weakness or areflexia. Deep tendon reflexes are usually normal.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: This is a central nervous system disorder that can cause a variety of neurological symptoms. Deep tendon reflexes are typically increased, and it does not present with an ascending pattern of weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guillain-Barré syndrome is characterized by acute, ascending, symmetrical, areflexic, flaccid quadriparesis, often following an infection

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction

 

Photophobia and watering in a 3-month-old child can be caused by various conditions. Here’s a closer look at each condition:

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: This condition typically presents with excessive tearing (lacrimation) due to blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. However, it does not cause photophobia. Photophobia indicates sensitivity to light, which is not a feature of nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • Congenital entropion: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This can lead to corneal abrasions, resulting in both photophobia and watering.
  • Congenital glaucoma: This is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to a triad of symptoms: photophobia, lacrimation, and blepharospasm (eyelid twitching). It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.
  • Congenital distichiasis: This condition involves an extra row of eyelashes, which can irritate the cornea, leading to corneal abrasions. This irritation can cause both photophobia and lacrimation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: As explained, this condition causes lacrimation but not photophobia. This makes it the to the question of which condition cannot cause photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is associated with excessive tearing but does not cause photophobia. Other conditions like congenital entropion, congenital glaucoma, and congenital distichiasis can cause both photophobia and watering due to corneal involvement and irritation.

questions.text: Which is the most common electrolyte imbalance seen in pyloric stenosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypokalemia

 

Pyloric stenosis is a condition where the opening from the stomach to the small intestine (the pylorus) becomes narrowed. This causes severe vomiting, which leads to the loss of stomach acid (hydrochloric acid). The loss of hydrochloric acid results in a metabolic alkalosis state.

 

In addition to the loss of stomach acid, vomiting leads to the depletion of various electrolytes, including sodium, potassium, and chloride. Among these, hypokalemia (low potassium levels) is the most common and significant electrolyte imbalance seen in pyloric stenosis. The continuous vomiting depletes potassium levels more profoundly than other electrolytes, making hypokalemia the predominant issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyponatremia: While sodium levels can be affected by vomiting, hyponatremia is not the most common or significant imbalance in pyloric stenosis. The primary issue revolves around potassium and chloride.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia: Hypochloremia (low chloride levels) is indeed a significant consequence of pyloric stenosis due to the loss of hydrochloric acid in vomit. However, it is not as clinically critical as hypokalemia in this condition.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Phosphate levels are generally not significantly affected by pyloric stenosis and are not considered a major electrolyte disturbance in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia is the most common and clinically significant electrolyte imbalance seen in pyloric stenosis due to persistent vomiting and the loss of stomach acid.

questions.text: A patient came with a history of mastectomy, 10 years ago. She had edema and bluish discolouration of the skin over the right upper limb. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lymphangiosarcoma

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario describes a patient with a history of mastectomy 10 years ago who presents with edema and bluish discoloration of the skin over the right upper limb. This clinical presentation is suggestive of lymphangiosarcoma, a rare malignant transformation of lymphatic vessels that can occur as a complication of mastectomy. The impaired lymphatic drainage following mastectomy leads to chronic lymphedema, which predisposes the affected limb to develop lymphangiosarcoma, also known as Stewart-Treves syndrome.

 

 

Unfortunately, lymphangiosarcoma carries a poor prognosis, with many patients surviving only 18 to 24 months after diagnosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Angioedema is a type of edema caused by increased vascular permeability, usually due to an allergic reaction or hereditary factors. It is not typically associated with a history of mastectomy.

 

Option B. Venous thrombosis can cause edema and skin discoloration but is not specifically linked to a history of mastectomy and would not explain the long interval (10 years) between the surgery and the onset of symptoms.

 

Option C. Angiosarcoma is a malignant tumor arising from blood vessels.

 

Educational objective:

 

Lymphangiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves syndrome) is a rare but serious complication of mastectomy, characterized by edema and skin discoloration of the affected limb due to malignant transformation of lymphatic vessels in the setting of chronic lymphedema. It carries a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male with a history of depression has been treated with fluoxetine for the past six months. He presented to the emergency department with altered consciousness and an ECG showing QT prolongation, with a QTc of 447 ms. Recently, he was prescribed an additional medication for chronic pain management. Which of the following drugs was most likely added to his regimen that could have contributed to his current condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methadone

 

Methadone is known to cause QT prolongation and can interact with fluoxetine, which is an SSRI and inhibits CYP450 enzymes, particularly CYP2D6, that metabolize many drugs including methadone. The inhibition can increase methadone levels, thus increasing the risk of QT prolongation and potential torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Piperidine is not a drug but rather a chemical class that includes various analgesics, such as fentanyl and its analogs. These medications do not typically cause QT prolongation; therefore, this would not be the likely cause of the patient's altered consciousness associated with QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Morphine is an opioid analgesic but is not commonly associated with QT prolongation. It is less likely to be the cause of the EKG changes in the scenario provided.

 

Option D. Tramadol is a centrally acting opioid analgesic, which also inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. It can potentially interact with fluoxetine, leading to increased serotonin levels and risk of serotonin syndrome. While it is less commonly associated with QT prolongation compared to methadone, it can still pose a risk, especially when combined with other drugs that affect serotonin levels or when overdosed.

 

Based on the clinical history and QTc value provided, methadone is the most likely cause of QT prolongation in this scenario, making option (a) the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methadone can cause QT prolongation, and when combined with fluoxetine, which inhibits its metabolism, the risk of QT prolongation and related cardiac issues increases significantly.
